thread.title: Tom Selleck cranky, but comforting, as Jesse Stone
thread.title_full: Tom Selleck cranky, but comforting, as Jesse Stone - San Antonio Express-News

author: mysanantonio.com
title: Tom Selleck cranky, but comforting, as Jesse Stone
text:
Photo: Chris Reardon / Crown Media Image 1 of / 5 5 Jesse Stone (Tom Selleck) takes an interest in the welfare of a teenage girl who has major problems at home in the latest installment of the murder mystery movie series, 'Lost in Paradise' on Hallmark Channel. October, 2015 Once a Los Angeles homicide detective, Police Chief Jesse Stone now presides over the quiet, seaside village of Paradise, Massachusetts. When the facts don't add up in a brutal Boston-area murder case, Jesse opens an investigation filled with surprises, unlikely suspects and grave danger. Though it's widely believed the murder was committed by an incarcerated serial killer, Jesse suspects another killer is at large and is hell-bent on bringing him to justice. Photo: Mackenzie Foy, Tom Selleck Credit: Copyright 2015 Crown Media United States, LLC/Photographer: Chris Reardon Jesse Stone (Tom Selleck) takes an interest in the welfare of a teenage girl who has major problems at home in the latest installment of the murder mystery movie series, 'Lost in Paradise' on Hallmark ... more Photo: Chris Reardon / Crown Media Image 2 of 5 Gloria Reuben returns as jazz singer Thelma Gleffey, a past love interest of Chief Jesse Stone (Tom Selleck), in the ninth installment of the murder mystery movie series, 'Lost in Paradise' on Hallmark Channel. October, 2015 Once a Los Angeles homicide detective, Police Chief Jesse Stone now presides over the quiet, seaside village of Paradise, Massachusetts. When the facts don't add up in a brutal Boston-area murder case, Jesse opens an investigation filled with surprises, unlikely suspects and grave danger. Though it's widely believed the murder was committed by an incarcerated serial killer, Jesse suspects another killer is at large and is hell-bent on bringing him to justice. 'Jesse Stone: Lost in Paradise,' airs on Hallmark Channel. When the facts don't add up in a brutal Boston-area murder case, Jesse opens an investigation filled with surprises, unlikely suspects and grave danger. Though it's widely believed the murder was committed by an incarcerated serial killer, Jesse suspects another killer is at large and is hell-bent on bringing him to justice. October, 2015 Once a Los Angeles homicide detective, Police Chief Jesse Stone now presides over the quiet, seaside village of Paradise, Massachusetts. When the facts don't add up in a brutal Boston-area murder case, Jesse opens an investigation filled with surprises, unlikely suspects and grave danger. Though it's widely believed the murder was committed by an incarcerated serial killer, Jesse suspects another killer is at large and is hell-bent on bringing him to justice. 'Jesse Stone: Lost in Paradise' airs on Hallmark Channel. October, 2015 Once a Los ... more Photo: Chris Reardon /Crown Media Image 5 of 5 Tom Selleck returns as police chief Jesse Stone in his signature murder-mystery movie series. Hallmark Channel picked up the ninth chapter, 'Lost in Paradise,' and will premiere it Oct. 18. Tom Selleck returns as police chief Jesse Stone in his signature murder-mystery movie series. Hallmark Channel picked up the ninth chapter, 'Lost in Paradise,' and will premiere it Oct. 18. Photo: Chris Reardon / Crown Media Tom Selleck cranky, but comforting, as Jesse Stone 1 / 5 Back to Gallery Judging by the uproar I hear any time CBS’ “Blue Bloods” gets pre-empted by a Spurs game, not to mention the queries I regularly receive from people who sorely miss the Jesse Stone movies, Tom Selleck continues to be a big favorite in San Antonio.
It’s easy to see why after watching him in the latest mystery thriller in the Stone franchise.
Yes, you heard me. After a three-year hiatus, Selleck and his signature cranky and damaged police gumshoe are back.
After CBS passed on doing more Jesse Stone, Crown Media Family Networks , which already runs marathons of these movies to enthusiastic response, came to the rescue.
“Jesse Stone: Lost in Paradise,” the ninth in the series, will premiere at 8 p.m. Sunday on Hallmark Channel. It airs again at 8 p.m. Oct. 25 on Hallmark Movies & Mysteries channel, preceded by a string of past Stone flicks.
Several staples return alongside Selleck, including Gloria Reuben (“Mr. Robot”) as the jazz singer with whom Jesse got intimate in the past and carries a torch for still. William Devane also reprises his role as Dr. Dix, the effectively frank therapist who helps Jesse work through emotional problems frequently fueled by too much scotch.
Guest stars include former “90210” heartthrob Luke Perry in an uncharacteristic role. He’s a serial killer.
As usual, however, it’s Selleck who commands the screen with the subdued intensity he’s brought to the title character for 10 years.
At 70, he is still one of the most handsome and charismatic actors around. Those famous dimples have only deepened with age, and the rugged cheek crevices add even more interest to his face.
The movie, once again, is inspired by the writings of Robert B. Parker , executive-produced by Selleck, who plays the police chief in a fictional Massachusetts town called Paradise.
Maybe it’s the moody music, the muted photography or the deliberately slow pace. There’s something oddly comforting about this series, even when the killings at each chapter’s core are horrific, such as the central homicide in “Lost in Paradise.”
The movie opens with Jesse feeling so restless he’s drinking more than he should. He’s done too effective a job cleaning up crime in Paradise.
He lives alone in a cozy home by the sea, continues to be hung up on his ex-wife and doesn’t even have Reggie, his beloved golden retriever — “my conscience” is what Jesse called him — for company. (Joe the Dog, who portrayed Reggie, died in 2013.)
A technology dinosaur, Jesse never texts and he abhors Facebook and similar sites.
“The average kid on social media has the attention span of eight seconds; that’s one second less than a goldfish,” he grumbles.
Realizing he needs an absorbing case to sink his teeth into, he takes the train into Boston to consult with assistant state homicide commander Sydney Greenstreet ( Leslie Hope ), another old paramour. She hands him a stack of cold cases, which includes the recent murder of a woman named Mavis that many believe already has been solved.
However, Jesse’s instincts tell him otherwise, and a jailhouse visit with the suspect — a scuzzy killer of women known as “The Boston Ripper” (Perry) — cements this feeling. He denies responsibility for Mavis, even though she, like the other victims, was carved up in the Ripper’s trademark style.
Jesse’s biggest motivation doesn’t come from a human, however. Instead, he’s tugged by an Irish setter named Steve, Mavis’ dog, who’s now a ward of Boston Animal Services . Told that Steve has issues and likely will be put down, Jesse takes him home, and yes, the heartbroken dog serves as his new “conscience.”
In fact, the scenes with the pooch are some of the most memorable as we’re taken on a twisty-turny path toward Mavis’ killer.
Along the way, Jesse befriends and helps a 13-year-old girl whose mother is plagued by addiction problems that, as we know by now, our protagonist has been familiar with much of his adult life.
“Lost in Paradise” is a decent whodunit, but the beauty of the movie, as always, lies with its deliciously melancholy execution and, of course, Selleck’s layered and quietly magnetic performance, which once again adds to his status as one of TV’s stalwart greats.
Jeanne Jakle ’s column appears Wednesdays and Sundays in mySA, and she blogs at Jakle’s Jacuzzi on mySA.com. Email her at jjakle@express-news.net.
